newsitem.title: GERMANY: SAP says staff did not trade shares near announcement. [CORRECTED 21:15 GMT]
newsitem.headline: SAP says staff did not trade shares near announcement. [CORRECTED 21:15 GMT]

text.p: (Corrects headline and text to make clear staff had not traded shares.)

Software house SAP AG, facing an insider trading probe, said on Wednesday that staff with access to confidential information had not engaged in trading shares around the time of a critical October 23, 1996, announcement.

Employees who knew that third quarter growth would weaken have sworn they did not engage in share trading based on that information, supervisory board chairman Bernd Thiemann said at the German company's annual general meeting.
Chief executive Dietmar Hopp also told shareholders that 71 employees, including 51 at the Walldorf headquarters, knew by October 18 third quarter results would fall below expectations.
After the announcement of third quarter results on October 22, SAP shares plunged 23 percent.
Frankfurt prosecutors are investigating whether SAP employees, relatives or friends used insider information in share or derivative trades around that time.
Members of SAP's supervisory and management boards have signed statements they at no time used insider information for trading.
